page.title: 18PLANTLIFE AROUND GRASSMOOR.
page.content: The whole area has little clumps of trees and the hedges around the fields have not been disturbed except where the pit tips are being removed. The most common trees are ash, oak, beech, sycamore and chestnuts. The hedges are mostly hawthorn with some elder, willow and holly in between them. A wide variety of wild flowers and grasses share the hedgerows. There are hardly any evergreen trees. The elm trees have been attacked by Dutch Elm disease and a large number in the area have died or been cut down Two have been taken from Grassmoor School grounds and four more from the park opposite. The children favour the chestnut tree which in the autumn provides them with fruit for their 'conker' competitions.
